Graphical abstract The design of efficient nanostructured catalysts is highly desirable for promoting the hydrogenation of 4-carboxybenzaldehyde (4-CBA), which are the key process of hydrorefining of crude terephthalic acid (CTA) to pure terephthalic acid (PTA). Herein, the Pt-FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts were developed and proved to be active for the selective hydrogenation of 4-CBA. As a result, the excellent 4-hydroxymethylbenzoic acid (4-HMBA) selectivity (85%) and benzoic acid (BA) selectivity (88%) were achieved on Pt-FeNi@C and Pt/C, respectively. In comparison with the commercial Pd/C catalyst, the Pt-FeNi@C catalyst exhibits excellent activity (97%) and reduces the occurrence of decarbonylation. Moreover, the Pt-FeNi@C catalyst exhibits excellent recyclability: the catalytic activity did not decrease significantly after four reaction cycles. In combination with detailed characterization, the Pt-FeNi@C catalyst has porous graphene core-shell architecture and remarkable electron transfer capacity. This work may provide some inspirations for the exploration of new PTA hydrofining catalysts. Keywords Pt 4-Carboxybenzaldehyde Hydrogenation Metals@carbon MOF-derived 1 Introduction Recently, metals@carbon composites have gained substantial attention as an excellent candidate for the noble metal nanoparticle (NMNP) catalyst support [1]. The metal@carbon composites are prepared by pyrolysis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) coordinated by metal ions and organic ligands [2–7]. The advantages for MOFs as precursors of metals@carbon composites include: a) the homogeneous distribution of metal ions and organic ligands lead to well-organized nanostructures on carbonization of the MOF [8]; b) after carbonization, a carbon shell appears over the metal surface which prevent their agglomeration and corrosion [9,10]; c) high porosity can afford more channels for hydrogen molecule and reactant diffusion [5]; d) the carbon composites converted from MOFs still remain the properties of the MOF [11–14]. Metals@carbon composites maintain most of advantages derived from their MOFs, such as high porosity, extremely surface area, tunable pore sizes, outstanding cycle lifetime, and so on [15,16]. Meanwhile, metals@carbon composites can serve as host to encapsulate metal nanoparticles (NPs) especially noble metals such as Pt [17], Pd [18], Rh [19] and Ru [20]. Therefore, NMNP-metals@carbon catalysts have been widely applied in catalysis [21–24], gas storage [25], environmental remediation and many other aspects [26–28]. Especially, utilization of NMNP-metals@carbon catalysts for hydrogenation reactions has been received considerable attention due to highly porous structures with an enhanced specific surface area which might improve the efficiency and catalytic activity, such as semihydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene [29], selectivity for hydrogenation of the carbonyl groups [30], hydrogenation of nitro compounds [31] and so on. Pt-based catalysts have been widely employed and demonstrated to be the effective catalysts for selectivity hydrogenation due to their excellent hydrogenation activity [32,33]. However, poor selectivity of monometallic Pt catalyst limits their application [34]. Therefore, the addition of one or more transition metals to Pt-based catalysts to form bimetallic or multimetallic catalysts has received extensive attention due to the electronic and geometric modifications [35]. Transition metals such as Fe, Ni, Co and Cu based MOFs exhibit excellent performance toward electrocatalytic applications and conventional thermal catalysis. In particular, MIL-101(Fe), a zerotype crystal structure consisting of two kinds of cages [36], is applied as a suitable precursor for obtaining high-performance nonprecious Fe-C catalyst. The unit components of MIL-101(Fe) has good stability, nontoxic nature, extremely large surface area and numerous active transition metal sites [37]. As well as Fe, Ni as an earth abundant transition metal possesses excellent corrosion resistance in many fields such as batteries, super capacitors and catalysis. Homogeneous multimetallic MOFs could be easily synthesized due to the good compatibility of metal ions with organic frameworks. Inspired by above advantages, we report here, for the first time, that Pt-based metals@carbon catalysts derived from MOFs represent excellent catalytic activity for hydrorefining of CTA to PTA as shown in Scheme 1 . The method of catalyst preparation follows a synthetic route previously developed by our research group [38,39]. The combination of Pt and metals@carbon composites derived from MOFs improves the properties of the catalyst and forms a unique bipyramidal morphology which was in-depth characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) and so on. Compared with commercial Pt/C (Pd/C) catalyst, Pt-FeNi@C catalyst not only has good activity and stability for hydrogenation of 4-CBA, but also has great differences in selectivity due to the excellent electron transfer capacity. These give the catalyst system great potential for industrial application in the PTA refining. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemical reagents Terephthalic acid (H2BDC), nickel acetylacetonate (Ni(acac)2), ferric trichloride hexahydrate (FeCl3·6H2O), chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6·6H2O) and N, N-dimethylformamide (DMF) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd. Ethanol and n-hexane were purchased from Beijing Chemical Reagent Company. All chemicals were used as received without further purification. 2.2 Synthesis of FeNi-MOFs FeNi-MOFs were synthesized according to our previously reported procedure [38]. Briefly, FeCl3·6H2O (1 mmol), Ni(acac)2 (0.5 mmol), H2BDC (1 mmol) and DMF (16 mL) were well mixed via ultrasonic and magnetic stirring and then placed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. After that the mixed solution maintained at 120 °C for 8 h. The final product was obtained by centrifugation, washing and drying. 2.3 Synthesis of Fe-MOFs or Ni-MOFs FeCl3·6H2O (1 mmol) or Ni(acac)2 (0.5 mmol), H2BDC (1 mmol) and DMF (16 mL) were well mixed via ultrasonic and magnetic stirring and then placed in a 50 mL Teflon-lined autoclave. After that the mixed solution maintained at 120 °C for 8 h. The final product was obtained by centrifugation, washing and drying. 2.4 Synthesis of Pt-FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C Pt-FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C were synthesized according to our previously reported procedure [39]. Typically, FeNi-MOF (100 mg) was uniformly dispersed in n-hexane (10 mL) via ultrasonication. Subsequently, a certain amount of H2PtCl6·6H2O solution (20 mmol, 200 μL) was added into the solution under vigorous stirring for 2 h. The final product was obtained via centrifugation and dried at 60 °C in an oven overnight, followed by calcination under Ar at 600 °C for 2 h (denoted as Pt-FeNi@C). The preparation of Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni-@C is the same as that of Pt-FeNi@C. 2.5 Catalyst characterization Power X-ray diffraction (XRD) was tested on a Brüker D8 Advance diffractometer at 40 kV and 40 mA for Cu Kα (λ = 0.15406). SEM images were observed on an ULTRA 55 SEM at 20 kV. TEM was performed on JEM-2100 at 200 kV. HRTEM was performed on a Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin at 200 kV. High- angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was carried out on Tecnai G2 F20 S-Twin HRTEM operating at 200 kV. XPS was measured on a PHI 5000 Versaprobe system using monochromatic Al Kα radiation (1486.6 eV). The C 1s graphitic peak is referred to as the reference (284.6 eV). Inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP- OES) was performed on iCAP7400 (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Renishaw Micro-Raman System 2000 spectrometer with spectral resolution of 2 cm−1 was used to record Raman spectra. A laser line at 532 nm of a He/Cd laser was used as an exciting source, and the output power was 20 mW. The spectra were recorded at a 1 cm−1 resolution with the condition of 50 s integral time at room temperature. N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms were conducted at −196 °C using a kubo X10000 static volumetric gas adsorption instrument. The samples were degassed at 200 °C for 3 h in a vacuum before measurements. The specific surface area of the sample was calculated from the adsorption branches (p/p0 : 0.05–0.20) by the Brunauer − Emmett − Teller (BET) method. The mesopore size distribution was calculated from desorption branches by the Barret − Joyner − Halenda (BJH) method, and the single point adsorption total pore volume was taken at the relative pressure of 0.96. 2.6 Catalytic reaction measurement The reaction of hydrogenation of 4-CBA was carried out in a 100 mL stirred autoclave reactor. 0.1 g 4-CBA and 50 mL water was added to the reactor in the presence of the catalyst (0.03 g), under a hydrogenation of 5 bar and 280 °C. After reacting at a stirring speed of 800 rpm/min for 1 h, the reactants and products are determined by ultra-high performance liquid chromatography Agilent 1290 equipped with a C18 column using acetonitrile–water binary mixture as gradient elution mobile phase. The performance of the catalyst is evaluated by the conversion of 4-CBA and the selectivity of yield products. The stability of the catalyst was obtained by six consecutive reactions. The product conversion and selectivity were calculated as follows: C n o v e r s i o n % = m o l o f p r o d u c t p r o d u c e d m o l o f s u b s t r a t e f e d × 100 % Selectivity ( % ) = m o l o f p r o d u c t p r o d c e d mol o f s u b s t r a t e c o n s u m e d × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst structure The texture properties of as-synthesized catalysts were determined using N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm and Barrett–Joyner–Halenda (BJH) pore size distribution curves. The as-synthesized catalysts exhibited type I isotherms with insignificant Ⅳ-type hysteresis loops, which was associated with capillary condensation in mesopores (Fig. 1 ). The calculated surface areas (pore volumes) of as-synthesized catalysts are shown in Table 1 . The surface areas and pore volumes of the Pt-FeNi@C catalyst are much higher than that of FeNi@C catalyst. The Pt-FeNi@C catalyst possesses the largest surface area and pore volume, which can facilitate mass diffusion/transport and provide more activity sites for conversation of 4-CBA. This is because larger surface area and pore volume can facilitate mass diffusion/transport and provide more activity sites. The as-obtained Pt-based catalysts were characterized by SEM and TEM. As shown in Fig. S2a and Fig. 2 a, the prepared FeNi@C and Pt-FeNi@C retained the bipyramidal morphology of the original FeNi-MOF. The TEM image shows that Pt-FeNi@C consists of numerous small nano-particles, and every nano-particle has a core (66 nm)-shell (12 nm) structure (Fig. 2b). As shown in Fig. S3, the Pt-Ni@C and Pt-Fe@C catalysts do not have the unique bipyramidal structure of Pt-FeNi@C catalysts. As revealed by HRTEM in Fig. 2c, the well-resolved lattice fringes with interplanar spacings of 0.21 nm and 0.34 nm can be indexed to the (111) plane of Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloy [17] and the typical layer spacing of graphitic carbon [39]. Meanwhile, Pt (111) facets with the interplanar spacings of 0.22 nm were detected for Pt-FeNi@C (Fig. 2d) [40]. The resulting HAADF-STEM and EDX element mappings indicate that the carbon element is mainly distributed outside of an individual nano-particle, while Fe, Ni, and Pt elements are basically distributed inside, which also indicate the formation of the metal@carbon (core-shell) structure (Fig. 2e–j). EDX analysis showed the presence of C, Fe, Ni and Pt elements. Besides, HRTEM-EDX of Pt-FeNi@C showed that the PtFeNi nanostructures should be highly dispersed in the carbon shell (Fig. 2j). The HRTEM image (Fig. S2c) shows a smaller lattice spacing (0.21 nm) than that of Pt-FeNi@C. This phenomenon indicated that a small amount of Pt was incorporated into the FeNi alloy to form PtFeNi ternary alloy [41]. Moreover, the chemical composition analyses of the as-obtained Pt-based catalysts verified by ICP-OES and EDAX are shown in Tables S1 and S2. The atomic ratio of Ni and Fe in Pt-FeNi@C and FeNi@C was close to 1:2. Meanwhile, the Pt content of all Pt-based catalysts was 0.66 wt%. Moreover, the XRD patterns of the FeNi@C and Pt-FeNi@C catalyst are shown in Fig. 3 . Three distinct diffraction peaks located at 2θ of 43.6°, 50.8° and 74.7° are indexed as (111), (200) and (220) planes of the cubic Fe0.64Ni0.36 alloy (JCPDS 47-1405), respectively (Fig. 3a). Furthermore, the Pt-FeNi@C catalyst exhibited similar diffraction patterns to FeNi@C, indicating that doping Pt into FeNi@C did not destroy the structure of the FeNi@C. This phenomenon is consistent with TEM images of Pt-FeNi@C and FeNi@C. When compared with the peak of FeNi@C, a little negative shift appears in the peak of Pt-FeNi@C. This phenomenon indicated that Pt atoms were introduced into the FeNi alloys (Fig. 3b) [42]. In addition, the XRD patterns of the Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C are shown in Fig. S4. There is no obvious difference between the diffraction patterns of PtFe@C and PtNi@C, but they are significantly different from Pt-FeNi@C and FeNi@C. This may be due to the formation of FeNi alloy in Pt-FeNi@C and FeNi@C, but not in Pt-Ni@C and Pt-Fe@C. Besides, the diffraction patterns of Pt (111) planes are note detected due to the low Pt loading in all Pt-based catalysts [43,44]. The formation of graphitic order of carbon shells was further proved by Raman spectroscopy. As shown in Fig. 3c, the G band at 1576.0 cm−1 is consistent with the in-plane vibration of sp2 carbon atoms, while the D band at 1336.1 cm−1 indicates the sp3-hybridized disordered structures [45,46]. Besides, the G band appears to be stronger than the D band, indicating that the Pt-FeNi@C and FeNi@C possess better degree of the graphitic crystalline structure. However, the I G/I D value of Pt-FeNi@C was higher than that of FeNi@C, demonstrating that the Pt-FeNi@C has better degree of the graphitic crystalline structure, which can be beneficial for achieving enhanced electronic conduction between neighboring Pt-FeNi alloy NPs [47]. To our delight, compared with FeNi@C, there is another relatively weak 2D broad peak located at 2681 cm−1 for Pt-FeNi@C, also demonstrating the existence of graphene carbon [48]. To further identify the surface compositions and chemical states of Pt-based catalysts, the Pt-FeNi@C and FeNi@C catalysts were detected by XPS (Fig. 4 ). There are two distinct metallic Pt peaks detected at 71.6 eV and 74.8 eV which are consistent with Pt 4f7/2 and Pt 4f5/2, respectively [49] (Fig. 4b). The binding energy of Pt 4f7/2 peak at 71.6 eV and 74.8 eV corresponds to Pt0 species [50,51]. It is worth noting that the Pt 4f peaks had a positive shift compared with that of pure Pt [52]. This phenomenon indicates that the electron transfer from Fe or Ni to Pt [35,53]. The peak position of Pt 4f7/2 of Pt-FeNi@C is shifted to 71.6 eV, indicating that Pt element gains extracharge from iron and nickel, which favors the CO adsorption during the hydrogenation [54] and improves the conversion and stability of 4-CBA. From Fig. 4c, there are three distinct metallic Fe peaks matching with Fe 2p detected at 707.5 eV, 710.7 eV and 712.7 eV which are assigned to Fe0, Fe2+ and Fe3+, respectively. Likewise, in the spectrum of Ni 2p, there appeared two chemically distinct species: metallic Ni (852.9 eV) and Ni2+ (855.2 eV) species, respectively (Fig. 4d). In addition, according to the peak areas, the percentages of metallic Fe0 and Ni0 in the Pt-FeNi@C catalyst are lower than those of the FeNi@C catalyst, which also indicates the existence of electron interactions between Pt, Fe and Ni. The XPS was also employed to investigate the chemical state of Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C (Fig. S5). The Fe 2p peaks could be deconvoluted to peaks at 710.5 and 712.5 eV representing Fe2+ and Fe3+, respectively (Fig. S5a), confirming the coexistence of Fe2+ and Fe3+ species on the catalyst surface. The Ni 2p peaks at 853.7 and 859.8 eV can be corresponded to Ni0 and Ni2+ species, respectively (Fig. S5c) [55]. The binding energy of Pt 4f region of Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts shows significant shifts to the binding energies of 0.6 eV and 0.1 eV, respectively, when compared with pure Pt metal peaks (70.9 eV) [56,57]. The positive shift compared to pure Pt is probably due to electron donation from Ni/Fe to Pt [58–60]. Compared with Pt-Ni@C, the peak deviation of Pt 4f in Pt-Fe@C is larger than that of in Pt-Ni@C indicating that the interaction for Pt-Fe system is stronger than that of the Pt-Ni system [44]. 3.2 Catalytic performances The hydrogenation scheme of 4-CBA is given as Fig. 5 a. With these Pt-based catalysts and Pt/C catalyst at hand, we are eager to investigate the catalytic performance in the selective hydrogenation of 4-CBA. The influence of Pt-based catalysts and Pt/C catalyst for the selective hydrogenation of 4-CBA is summarized in Fig. 5b. The generated products include 4-HMBA, p-toluic acid (P-TOL) and BA. The reactions were initially performed under 0.5 MPa H2 at 280 °C for 1 h in the screening series of various catalysts. There is only 4-HMBA in the 4-CBA hydrogenation products of FeNi@C, which indicates that FeNi alloy has a high hydrogenation selectivity for CO [61]. For the Pt-Fe@C catalyst, the generated products only include 4-HMBA and BA, suggesting that Fe favours the hydrogenation of CO over the decarboxylic reaction [2]. This is because electron-deficient Fe could attract the lone pair of oxygen in the carbonyl group via side-bonding interaction, which indicates that the presence of Fe can promote the hydrogenation selectivity of CO [60,62]. In addition, due to the anticlinal folded Pt-Fe skin [63], CO group can be more easily adsorbed and activated. Moreover the excellent 4-HMBA selectivity of Pt-Fe@C is due to the higher electron density of the surface Pt atoms [64]. However, for the Pt-Ni@C catalyst, the generated products not only include 4-HMBA and BA, but also have P-TOL which demonstrates that the hydrogenation effect of Ni on CO is not obvious [44,65]. This is because Ni has activity for homolytic-H2 dissociation to create hydride-like species attached on the Ni. The interaction between those hydride-like species and Pt can further hydrogenate the CO group to CH3 group. The variation of hydrogenation products of each catalyst with time is shown in Fig. 5d–g. As the reaction continues, 4-HMBA is the main product of Pt-based catalyst doped with Fe or Ni, while BA is the main product of Pt/C catalyst. The same results are also shown in Fig. 5b, 4-HMBA is the main product of the hydrogenation products of Pt-FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts. In contrast, when Pt/C catalyst is used, the main product is dramatically switched to BA in a selectivity of 88%. Therefore, the addition of iron and nickel into the Pt-based catalyst changes the hydrogenation selectivity of 4-CBA. The possible process of Pt-FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts in the hydrogenation of 4-CBA is illustrated in Scheme 2 . The H2 dissolved in the solution should be adsorbed and activated on the Pt surface to form hydrides [44]. And the CO bond of 4-CBA could be activated on the surface of Fe [66]. Then the activated H*-H* would react with the CO bond of 4-carboxybenzaldehyde to hydrogenate 4-CBA to p-TOL [67]. As can be seen from the results of XPS, compared to Pt/C catalyst, there are strong electron interactions between Pt and Fe or Ni in Pt-FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts which results in rich electron density of the surface of Pt atoms. Therefore, the higher electron density of Pt in Pt-FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts inhibits the decarbonylation of 4-CBA, consequently to high selectivity of 4-HMBA [68]. Compared to Pt/C catalyst, the main chemoselectivity of Pt-FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts were 4-HMBA (85%, 89% and 75%, respectively) instead of BA (Table S3). The FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts showed lower activity, only 20%, 63% and 29%, respectively. Notably, when Pt-FeNi@C was used as the catalyst, the conversion of 4-CBA was 97%, is higher than Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalyst (Fig. 5c). These results indicated that the combination of Pt and Fe/Ni is desirable for the chemoselective transformation of 4-CBA. We also investigated the effect of Pt-FeNi@C catalysts with different Pt loadings on the hydrogenation performance of 4-CBA. As can be seen in Fig. S6, when the Pt loading is 0.66 wt%, the conversion of 4-CBA is the highest, and when the Pt loading is 0.31 wt% and 1.61 wt%, the corresponding conversion are 81% and 72%, respectively. The hydrogenation selectivity of 4-CBA is consistent for Pt-FeNi@C catalysts with different Pt loadings, and only BA and 4-HMBA are found in the products. The reaction time versus 4-CBA conversion was shown in Fig. 5c. The 4-CBA conversion over Pt-FeNi@C is greater than the sum of Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts within 60 min. For an instance, at the initial reaction time of 10 min, the 4-CBA conversion over Pt-FeNi@C is nearly 90% which is greater than that of Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts (nearly 50% and 20% respectively). The 4-CBA conversion over Pt-FeNi@C is also greater than Pt/C catalyst. The turnover frequencies (TOFs) of Pt-FeNi@C (5515 h−1) calculated on the basis of total platinum is significantly higher than that of Pt/C (2826 h−1) calculated at the 4-CBA conversion of 70%. It has also been reported that Pd-based catalyst supported on SiC (TOFs = 5436 h−1) [69], Pd on mesoporous TiO2 nanotube (TOFs = 1127 h−1) [70] are active catalysts for the hydrogenation of 4-CBA. However, the results present above clearly show that the activity of our Pt-FeNi@C catalyst is higher than that Pd-based catalysts supported on SiC and on mesoporous TiO2 nanotube. 3.3 Catalyst stability To explore the stability of the catalyst, the Pt-FeNi@C catalyst was investigated as a representative for four consecutive reactions under the same conditions. After the reaction, the catalyst was easily separated through filtrating. It was used for the next run after washing and drying. As shown in Fig. 6 a, the Pt-FeNi@C catalyst exhibited excellent stability and reusability. The conversion of 4-CBA (~97%) is almost unchanged even after 4 cycles. In the four consecutive reactions, the main product of hydrogenation is 4-HMBA (~80%), with only a small amount of BA (~20%). Compared to Pt-FeNi@C catalyst, the conversion of 4-CBA on commercial Pd/C was 92%, 90%, 73%, and 60%, respectively, for the four successive reaction runs (Fig. 6b). This indicates that the stability of commercial Pd/C catalyst is lower than that of Pt-FeNi@C catalyst. Moreover, the main hydrogenation product of commercial catalysts is BA (~93%). During the hydrogenation of 4-CBA, BA is produced at the same time will produce CO, and the Pd/C catalyst would be poisoned at the presence of CO [71]. However, the Pt-FeNi@C catalyst showed excellent CO toxicity resistance, mainly owing to the addition of Fe and Ni enhanced the CO toxicity resistance of the catalyst [72]. To further check the catalyst stability, the catalyst after four times of use was detected using ICP (Table S3). To our delight, there is no obvious loss of Pt. In addition, we compared the Pt-FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts with other catalysts reported in the literature for the conversion of 4-CBA. The detailed comparison results are shown in Table 2 . The Pt-FeNi@C catalyst in this work catalyzes the largest 4-CBA with the least amount, and the conversion rate can reach 97%, which is consistent with the catalytic activity in other literatures. The BA selectivity of Pt-FeNi@C catalyst is only 15%, compared with 82% in Liu's work. These results indicate that Pt-FeNi@C catalyst has a stronger ability to inhibit decarbonylation reaction than other catalysts in the literature. Based on the above characterization results and 4-CBA hydrogenation performance of Pt-FeNi@C catalyst, the possible reasons for high activity and selectivity could be attributed to the following aspects. (a) Structure effect: the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm and BJH pore size distribution curve indicates that Pt-FeNi@C catalyst has larger specific surface area and good mesoporous structure. It is well known that the larger specific surface area can make the active sites evenly distributed and the mesoporous structure can facilitate mass diffusion/transport. Therefore, the hydrogenation activity is enhanced. Moreover, the unique core-shell structure demonstrated by TEM, HR-TEM and EDX can avoid the aggregation and dissolution of the Pt-FeNi alloy. This is why the stability of Pt-FeNi catalyst is higher than that of Pt/C catalyst. (b) electronic effect: according to XPS results, the peak of Pt 4f in Pt-FeNi@C catalyst is positively shifted compared with pure Pt which is due to the charge from Fe and Ni to Pt. As a result, the electron density of the Pt atom increases. The enhancement of Pt electron density not only increases the selectivity of 4-HMBA but also enhances the hydrogenation activity of 4-CBA. 4 Conclusion In summary, the Pt-FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts show unique electronic structure and catalytic properties for selectivity of 4-CBA in comparison with mono-metal Pt/C catalyst. Superior selectivity to 4-HMBA was achieved by Pt-FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalyst. With dropping of Fe or Ni into Pt-based catalysts, the BA selectivity was disappeared or declined. As a result, about 88% selectivity to BA was obtained on Pt/C catalyst without dropping of Fe or Ni. Based on the detailed characterization and 4-CBA hydrogenation experiment, we found that Pt-FeNi@C catalyst showed excellent hydrogenation activity and superior selectivity due to the unique core-shell structure and fast electron transfer capability. However, the conversion of both Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C are lower than that of Pt-FeNi@C, owing to the good surface area and electron transfer capacity of Pt-FeNi@C. All the catalysts have a small degree of decarbonylation reaction during the hydrogenation process of 4-CBA, which provides important guidance for the study of PTA hydrogenation catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The design of efficient nanostructured catalysts is highly desirable for promoting the hydrogenation of 4-carboxybenzaldehyde (4-CBA), which are the key process of hydrorefining of crude terephthalic acid (CTA) to pure terephthalic acid (PTA). Herein, the Pt-FeNi@C, Pt-Fe@C and Pt-Ni@C catalysts were developed and proved to be active for the selective hydrogenation of 4-CBA. As a result, the excellent 4-hydroxymethylbenzoic acid (4-HMBA) selectivity (85%) and benzoic acid (BA) selectivity (88%) were achieved on Pt-FeNi@C and Pt/C, respectively. In comparison with the commercial Pd/C catalyst, the Pt-FeNi@C catalyst exhibits excellent activity (97%) and reduces the occurrence of decarbonylation. Moreover, the Pt-FeNi@C catalyst exhibits excellent recyclability: the catalytic activity did not decrease significantly after four reaction cycles. In combination with detailed characterization, the Pt-FeNi@C catalyst has porous graphene core-shell architecture and remarkable electron transfer capacity. This work may provide some inspirations for the exploration of new PTA hydrofining catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Multicomponent Pt-based catalyst for highly efficient chemoselective hydrogenation of 4-carboxybenzaldehyde
